results.title: Stories from Yambuk Youth
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, David Withers, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Five boys from Yambuk talk about what it means to be young in a small regional town and the various activities the town has to offer. They tell of the fun times growing up in the country, what they would like to change about the world and their ambitions for the future.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kim Montgomery, David Withers, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI

results.title: Deen Maar: Past, Present & Future
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Geoff Clarke takes us on a tour of the Deen Maar property and explains why the island and the land is such a significant location for the local Indigenous people and is of importance to the Yambuk area. He discusses the challenge of incorporating modern industry on such a sensitive site, installing wind turbines on the land, which generates an economic return for the community while achieving a compromise in protecting the cultural significance of the site.
results.description: Geoff Clarke takes us on a tour of the Deen Maar property and explains why the island and the land is such a significant location for the local Indigenous people and is of importance to the Yambuk area. He discusses the challenge of incorporating modern industry on such a sensitive site, installing wind turbines on the land, which generates an economic return for the community while achieving a compromise in protecting the cultural significance of the site.

results.title: The Yambuk Slide
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description:
The Yambuk Slide is a local icon, a place where generations have come to enjoy the freedom and fun that a slide in the middle of a sand dune can deliver.
Originally built in 1982, when the slide was likely to be removed it caused much upset with the locals, one threatening to chain himself to the slide. The new slide does not have the speed of the old one, but it still keeps kids entertained and parents happy.

results.title: Sea Changers
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: More and more people are moving to Port Fairy to be part of a strong, creative and social community. We meet Katie Wise who came to Port Fairy for a visit, and has been there for 10 years now, managing the school canteen and teaching the kids the benefit of healthy food. For Helen and Ben Fennessy, Port Fairy is a place that gives them great solitude to be able to do what they like creatively. Judy and Victor Gillatt explored the town while on holiday in 1973, and the more they explored, the more they liked.

results.title: Ted: The Kite Man
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ted the kite man is a Port Fairy icon. A long time resident, Ted has a kite shop, a big heart, and a contagious philosophy as he encourages kids to explore the winds and the outdoors flying their kites. He and his partner build kites with 3,000 children a year and he believes flying a kite helps you forget all your concerns of the day while participating in this peaceful activity.

results.title: Port Fairy Connections
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Essie Warmuth introduces us to the various social, political and community groups that thrive in Port Fairy. There’s the bike group that rides every morning, rain, hail or shine. Next we go indoors to visit a book club that has entertained and engaged a group of women for over 30 years. These women have shared books, births, weddings and funerals over the years. Finally, a community action group, in collaboration with the local IGA, devoted to stamping out the use of plastic bags in Port Fairy. These groups illustrate the diverse interests of this small town as well as creating a strong sense of community for the locals.

results.title: Growing up on Cummera
results.creator_credit: May Andy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: May is a Yorta Yorta woman who grew up on Cummera Gunja mission. She warmly reflects on her days there, swimming and listening the the elders tell their stories. Moved away from her community, she experienced racism and prejudice but from those experiences learnt to overcome the boundries that others set up for her. She has since committed to a lifetime of learning and teaching and linking children and family back to their communities.

results.title: Growing up in Fitzroy
results.creator_credit: Marlene Scerri, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Marlene (Scerri) Young gives us a picture of what it was like to grow up in Fitzroy in the 1950s. She lovingly tells of the closeness to her extended family, the friends coming to stay over and the strong sense of community, especially the Christmas parades down Smith Street.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Marlene Scerri, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Black people power
results.creator_credit: Kelvin Onus-King, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Kevin Onus-King learnt that ‘you only get what you want when you fight for it’ and he learnt this in more ways than one over the years. He takes us back through the history of Indigenous activists in Fitzroy and how this area was a hot bed of political activity as he was growing up. He later became strongly involved in the fight for better conditions and has taken that fight across Australia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kelvin Onus-King, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

He later became strongly involved in the fight for better conditions and has taken that fight across Australia.

results.title: Victimised, Assimalised, Correctionalised
results.creator_credit: Howard Edwards, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As a child, Howard Edwards was shunted from orphanage to orphanage. Made a ward of the state in 1956, he was abused and beaten wherever he was sent. His incarceration didn’t end there and for much of his adult life Howard was a target for police and he was often locked up at the slightest provocation. A large part of Howard’s journey towards healing involved reconnecting with his family, his work in the community and on the board of the Aboriginal Health Care Service.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Howard Edwards, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: As a child, Howard Edwards was shunted from orphanage to orphanage. Made a ward of the state in 1956, he was abused and beaten wherever he was sent. His incarceration didn’t end there and for much of his adult life Howard was a target for police and he was often locked up at the slightest provocation. A large part of Howard’s journey towards healing involved reconnecting with his family, his work in the community and on the board of the Aboriginal Health Care Service.
description_for_label: As a child, Howard Edwards was shunted from orphanage to orphanage. Made a ward of the state in 1956, he was abused and beaten wherever he was sent. His incarceration didn’t end there and for much of his adult life Howard was a target for police and he was often locked up at the slightest provocation. A large part of Howard’s journey towards healing involved reconnecting with his family, his work in the community and on the board of the Aboriginal Health Care Service.
